urlLink Google's IPO and the Valley's arrogance. Jim Cramer couldn't be more right. My personal experience with Google (other than using it for search, which I still love) was with Reservoir Partners where we tried paid search for a few campaigns. High prices, low response and we kept getting suspended (and having to pay to reinitiate) for low clickthrough. I'd be inclined to write it off to bad marketing but we were concurrently using Overture and getting much better results. Search Engine Marketing is a 2003 trend that's already over the hill. Not useless, but past its prime. The world is full of SEM consultants who will soon be looking for the next hype wave to ride, and if that describes you, then you should start thinking about it right now. This is all part of a broader theme I've been watching, also illustrated by the fight over urlLink expensing options. Google is not the only company in Silicon Valley that's over the hill - much of the rest of the valley is as well. The smart VCs know this and are pushing their overvalued charges through Wall Street as fast as they can while they can still get out. I know that I, for one, wouldn't go near the Google IPO with my money. My god, I actually agree with urlLink Dan Gillmor - albeit for completely different reasons. Maybe it won't be so bad if Google screws it up after all...
